awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Impact of Aerosol Viscosity, Phase Separation, and Internal Structure on Isoprene-Derived SOA (Secondary Organic Aerosol) Formation
awd_abstract_narration:
The project strives to minimize the gap between measurements and models that characterize the formation rates, concentrations, and spatial distributions of small organic particles in the atmosphere. Laboratory studies will be conducted in the UNC Environmental Chamber Facility to measure key physicochemical properties of aerosol and gas phase products. The results will be applied to improve models of secondary organic aerosol (SOA) formation to better inform policy decisions about air quality, human health, and climate.

The PIs will test the hypothesis that higher viscosity and phase-separation will suppress the reactive uptake of isoprene epoxydiols (IEPOX). The four objectives of the experimental plan to test this hypothesis include the (1) determination of the reactive uptake of IEPOX as a function of particle viscosity; (2) determination of the reactive uptake of IEPOX on particles with complex morphologies; (3) identification of the molecular composition and physicochemical properties of the IEPOX-derived SOA constituents for different viscosities and morphologies; and (4) characterization of volatile products resulting from reactive uptake chemistry of IEPOX.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to improve understanding of the formation rates, concentrations, and spatial distributions of small organic particles in the atmosphere. The goal was to help reduce the gap between measurements and models used to predict secondary organic aerosol (SOA), which is a key component of fine particulate matter (PM2.5) that can lead to poor air quality and play a role in the climate system. Laboratory studies were conducted in the UNC Environmental Chamber Facility with flow tubes, which together allowed for the study of a range of conditions and timescales for atmospheric SOA formation.

The key hypothesis we tested was that high viscosity coatings would suppress the reactive uptake of a key SOA precursor, isoprene epoxydiols (IEPOX). Since isoprene is the most abundant non-methane hydrocarbon emitted into Earth’s atmosphere, examining SOA formation potential from IEPOX is critical since it is the most abundant isoprene-derived oxidation product.  We found that pre-existing SOA coatings do inhibit uptake of IEPOX, but that the precursor gases that lead to the SOA coating are important in determining the extent of IEPOX uptake and the resulting viscosity. We also found organosulfates are a key class of compounds that form within these particles, leading to significant changes in particle viscosity, morphology, and ultimately limit further uptake of IEPOX (as well as other reactive gases). The acidity of particles ended up being a key variable, which was probed systematically. Lastly, new methods were developed to measure these particles and their components, such as organosulfates.

The results described above represent the intellectual merit of the project, leading to an overall improved understanding of how existing SOA coatings in PM2.5 affect the SOA formation from the multiphase chemistry (or reactive uptake) of IEPOX, and resulting changes to particles after IEPOX uptake to the SOA-coated inorganic particles. The results are already being used to improve atmospheric models of SOA formation to better inform policy decisions about air quality, human health, and climate. Broader impacts of this work include training and mentorship of numerous students across a range of educational levels (high school through graduate students) and postdoctoral scholars, as well as helping to improve our understanding of the impacts of SOA within PM2.5 in a changing climate.
